bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: George Nelson Hill was a farmer, Republican politician, state senator, and educator, of Northwest Township (Brunswick County), North Carolina. Former Union Army veteran, originally from Newton, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Diary dated June 1869-August 1872 (156 pages) mainly concerns farming, including some references to rice, laborers, a grape and scuppernong vineyard and wine making; county Republican politics, politicians, and elections; and local persons and communities, including visits to Wilmington and Smithville. Other diary topics include: state Republican politics and elections; local churches; the school committee and the establishment of a black school; a visit to Newton, Massachusetts (1871-1872); a trip to the North Carolina coast (Aug. 1871); the burning of the C.S.S. North Carolina (Sept. 1871); and occasional references to blacks, the Ku Klux Klan, the Democratic opposition, a cooperative association (1872), and a local post of the Grand Army of the Republic (1872).

The volume also contains miscellancous records, 1869-1870s; farm accounts and memoranda, including accounts for men and women laborers; purchases of goods; travel expenses; and occasional notations about politicians and elections.

Addition includes letters from Hill to his niece "Eva." Contains letters from: Raleigh while he was in the North Carolina State Senate; Washington D.C., where he worked in the U.S. Treasury Department; Smithfield, North Carolina; and Wilmington, North Carolina.
